sentence.text: Patient 2 is a 3-year-old girl and the first child to healthy, non-consanguineous Argentinian parents.
She was born as term following an uncomplicated pregnancy with a birth weight of 3.15 kg (50th centile), birth length of 49 cm (50th centile), and a head circumference of 37 cm (+ 2SD).
She had a mild persistent ductus arteriosus.
A complex, multi-sutural craniosynostosis was diagnosed during the second month of life.
Surgical intervention was undertaken in two stages, namely, at 2 and 15 months, respectively.
She has macrocephaly, dolichocephaly, a high forehead, telecanthus, epicanthic folds, broad nasal bridge, a long philtrum, full cheeks, and an everted lower lip.
She has small teeth with enamel dysplasia.
Like Patient 1, her hair is fine and sparse hair, a short neck with excess skin folds, and brachysyndactyly with fifth finger clinodactyly bilaterally (Fig. 2).
In the first year of life she also developed frequent respiratory infections, and testing for cystic fibrosis was negative.
Renal ultrasound scan showed normal size of both kidneys.
At the age of 2 years and 5 months, she remains macrocephalic with normal weight and height.
